doc.previous: Differential equations first came into existence with the invention of calculus by Newton and Leibniz. In Chapter 2 of his 1671 work "Methodus fluxionum et Serierum Infinitarum",[1] Isaac Newton listed three kinds of differential equations: those involving two derivatives (or fluxions) and only one undifferentiated quantity ; those involving and ; and those involving more than two derivatives.
